title: RL31370
content: The FY2008 budget request for the Department of State and Broadcasting Board of Governors (BBG) includes funding for U.S. contributions to United Nations (U.N.) International Organizations and U.N. Peacekeeping. The Administration's request to Congress on February 5, 2007, includes a 10.5% increase for the Department of State and a 3.8% increase for international broadcasting. The FY2008 budget request for the Department of State and Broadcasting Board of Governors (BBG) includes a 3.8% increase over FY2007, but a 1.7% decline from FY2006. The White House sent two supplemental funding requests to Congress for U.S. operations in Iraq and Afghanistan. The House and Senate passed their versions of the supplemental emergency funding bill for State Department operations in Iraq, security, exchanges, and international peacekeeping. The Senate bill includes $1.1 billion for State Department operations in Iraq, security, exchanges, international organizations, and peacekeeping. It also provides $10 million for international broadcasting. The House and Senate passed the conference report on April 25th and 26th, respectively. The President vetoed the supplemental on May 1st, and Congress was unable to override the veto. In February 2006, the President sent his FY2007 budget request totaling $9,502.4 million for State and $671.9 million for international broadcasting. The 109th Congress passed $1,737.7 million in supplemental funding for the Department of State and international broadcasting. The 109th Congress did not enact regular appropriations for State and the Broadcasting Board of Governors. Instead, they passed a series of continuing resolutions with funding based on FY2006 amounts or FY2007 levels. The FY2007 appropriation was passed by the 110th Congress on February 15, 2007. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice announced her vision for U.S. diplomacy in the 21st Century on January 18, 2006. State Condoleezza Rice introduced the concept of "transformational diplomacy" to align with President Bush's mission of promoting democracy globally. This approach involves relocating over 200 positions from Europe and Washington, DC to key regions like Africa, South Asia, and the Middle East. Additionally, regional public diplomacy centers are being established in Europe and the Middle East. The State Department is implementing transformational diplomacy by establishing public diplomacy centers in Europe and the Middle East, as well as regional centers for information technology. This includes American Presence Posts and Virtual Presence Posts to enhance America's presence through interactive online discussions. Plans also include enhancing training for technology and languages, requiring diplomats to be experts in at least two regions and fluent in two languages. The State Department is implementing transformational diplomacy by requiring diplomats to be experts in two regions and fluent in two languages. They must serve in challenging posts and work with other federal agencies. The FY2008 budget includes funds for job repositioning, language training, Foreign Service modernization, and public diplomacy. The budget request for Transformational Diplomacy included $102.8 million. The U.S. Embassy in Iraq has over 1,000 staff from 12 agencies. The FY2007 and FY2008 supplemental requests would mainly fund State Department operations in Iraq, including security upgrades and public diplomacy efforts. The budget request includes $200 million for U.N. international peacekeeping activities, $71.5 million for migration and refugee assistance, $30 million for emergency assistance, and $10 million for Arabic language broadcasting. The House and Senate passed their versions of the supplemental funding bill for State Department operations in Iraq and international peacekeeping. The Senate bill, like the House bill, provides $10 million for international broadcasting. The President vetoed the FY2007 emergency supplemental, which Congress was unable to override. The FY2008 emergency funding request includes $1,881.6 million for ongoing U.S. Mission operations in Iraq and $53 million for U.N. Assistance Missions in Afghanistan and Iraq, with an additional $35 million for Migration and Refugee Assistance. The FY2006 Emergency Supplemental of $1,497 million was requested for State's Diplomatic and Consular Programs budget account to cover Iraq operations and security. The final measure included funding for various purposes such as State's Inspector General, exchanges in Iran, U.N. peacekeeping, and international broadcasting in Iran. The President signed the measure into law on June 15, 2006. The State Department's mission is to advance and protect U.S. interests worldwide through various responsibilities. The State Department oversees activities in over 180 countries with 50 U.S. government agencies. The Diplomatic and Consular Programs account funds overseas operations and foreign policy activities. The FY2008 budget request is $4,942.7 million, a 14.5% increase from FY2007. The FY2008 budget request for Embassy Security, Construction and Maintenance (ESCM) is $964.8 million, with $700 million allocated for worldwide security upgrades. This is a 13.2% decrease from the FY2006 funding level. Congress had previously allocated $1 billion for security upgrades following the embassy bombings in Africa in 1998. The FY2008 budget request for Embassy Security, Construction and Maintenance (ESCM) is $964.8 million, with $700 million allocated for worldwide security upgrades. The Administration is seeking $792.5 million for regular ESCM and $806.9 million for security upgrades, totaling $1,599.4 million, a 7.4% increase over previous years. The request includes $486.4 million for Educational and Cultural Exchanges, a 9.1% increase over FY2007. The FY2008 budget request includes $486.4 million for Educational and Cultural Exchanges, representing a 9.1% increase over FY2007. Additionally, the Capital Investment Fund (CIF) is allocated $70.7 million, a 21.7% increase over previous years. In FY2006, a program was funded at $68.5 million, with $116 million from expedited passport fee collections allocated for Technology Investments. No funding was provided for the Centralized Information Technology Modernization Program in FY2007. U.S. contributions to the United Nations and peacekeeping operations have been affected by various issues in recent years. Efforts to reform the United Nations organization have been a focus of congressional attention since 2004, with a particular emphasis on addressing sexual exploitation and abuse in peacekeeping operations. Legislative proposals have been crafted to ensure comprehensive U.N. reform, including oversight of reforms initiated in 2005. There is also consideration of increasing the U.S. contribution cap for U.N. peacekeeping assessments. Contributions to International Organizations (CIO) provide funds for U.S. membership in international organizations and multilateral foreign policy activities. The President's FY2008 request for this account is $1,354.4 million, a 17.6% increase over FY2007. Contributions to International Peacekeeping Activities (CIPA) support multilateral peacekeeping efforts. Congressional focus on U.N. reform includes addressing sexual exploitation and abuse in peacekeeping operations. Legislative proposals aim to ensure comprehensive U.N. reform and consider increasing the U.S. contribution cap for U.N. peacekeeping assessments. The United States supports multilateral peacekeeping efforts through payment of its share of the U.N. assessed peacekeeping budget. The FY2008 request totals $1,107.0 million, a 4% decline from FY2006 funding level. The International Commissions account includes various commissions. The FY2008 request of $113.5 million represents a significant increase over previous levels. The Asia Foundation is a nonprofit organization supporting democratic processes in Asia, receiving government and private sector contributions. The FY2008 request is $10 million, 27.5% below the FY2006 level. The estimated funding for FY2007 is $13.8 million. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, FY2004 established a trust fund for the International Center for Middle Eastern-Western Dialogue with $6.9 million for operations in Istanbul, Turkey. Despite no FY2005 funding request, Congress allocated $7.3 million. FY2006 saw a request for $850,000 but Congress approved $5 million. For FY2007, $750,000 was requested but no funding was allocated in the FY2008 budget. The National Endowment for Democracy is a private nonprofit organization. The National Endowment for Democracy, established during the Reagan Administration, supports democratic institutions in over 90 countries. Critics argue it duplicates US government programs and could operate with private funding. The FY2008 budget request is $80 million, an 8.1% increase from FY2006. The 109th Congress created a Democracy Fund in FY2006, providing an additional $15.25 million for NED. The estimated FY2007 funding level is $74 million. The East-West Center in Honolulu and the North-South Center in Miami promote understanding and cooperation among nations. The FY2008 request for the East-West Center is $10 million, a 47.4% decrease from FY2006. The North-South Center began receiving federal subsidies in 1991. The FY2007 funding level for U.S. government international broadcasting is set at $19 million. The Broadcasting Board of Governors oversees Voice of America, Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, Radio Free Asia, and the Middle East Broadcasting Network. Congress emphasized the importance of credibility in U.S. international broadcasting during a reorganization debate in 1999. The Broadcasting Board of Governors (BBG) oversees international broadcasting activities with a budget request of $668.2 million for FY2008. This includes funding for Voice of America (VOA), Capital Improvements, and Broadcasting to Cuba. The BBG plans to eliminate several VOA services and reduce others, such as VOA and RFE/RL service in Ukrainian, Tibetan, and Romanian. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 grants the Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security exclusive authority over visa issuance, including regulations, employee assignments, and training. Former VOA directors are appealing to Congress to reverse proposed cuts, while BBG's FY2008 request includes a $20 million increase for Middle East Broadcasting network funds. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 grants the Secretary of State and consular officers authority to refuse visa applications. Within one year, reports to Congress on visa issuance implementation and improvements are required. In Saudi Arabia, the third-party screening program will end, with DHS personnel reviewing visa applications. The Department of State can use machine-readable visa fees for expenditures, totaling $602.9 million for FY2004. The State Department uses visa fees for border security programs, technology, and personnel. Funds for FY2004 were $602.9 million, increasing to $862 million for FY2008.
